main.description: Official OpenBoxes website - Open source logistics management information system

ProductOverview.Summary: OpenBoxes (OB) is a purpose-built open source logistics management information system designed to serve the supply-chain management demands of public health systems.
ProductOverview.PrimaryFunctionality: Logistics management information system for supply chain management
ProductOverview.Users: The primary users of OpenBoxes are pharmacists and depot managers at hospitals or medical supply warehouses in low-resource settings. These are often users at a central hub that manage warehousing, forecasting, and distribution for a network of smaller health facilities.

Reach.SummaryOfReach: The largest implementation of OpenBoxes is in Haiti, where it is used in 12 government-run hospitals with the support of Partners in Health. Partners in Health also uses the software for supported facilities in 5 additional countries. OpenBoxes has been implemented by the government in the State of Mexico, and is currently being implemented by the MOHSS Dominica for their Central Medical Store. Several small non-profits in the Caribbean and Africa use the software to manage their logistics. Commercial entities also use the software, most notably the Commonwealth Games in the UK.

Maturity.SummaryOfMaturity: All maturity model assessments are self-reported by the funded organization leading the development of the global good. The scores for Inclusive Design, Climate Resilience and Low Carbon are not available as this assessment was done using the previous version of the maturity model.

Community.DescriptionOfCommunity: OpenBoxes is developed and maintained by Partners in Health with support from the global health logistics community.

HostAnchorOrganization.name: Partners in Health
HostAnchorOrganization.description: Global health organization focused on health equity

Sustainability.Description: The solution is supported through a combination of grant funding and funding from implementing organizations. Partners in Health provides the bulk of the financial support and also manages grant funding. Americares and Kuehne-Nagel have committed significant funding over the past 2 years. Other implementing organizations contribute small amounts for software support or for specific projects.
